Great idea.  Obviously in what I hope is your initial beta testing phase.  It has potential but needs a lot of work.  Well worth the money I paid for it.  (It was free.  :D )  Make it more interactive where she asks me questions and responds to my answer either verbally or with a look or laugh.  Make it so I  can go off script and ask her my questions.  I promise I won't be asking her about rocket science or quantum theory.

The characters seem as though they are trying to be all things to all people. This leaves them devoid of any specific sexuality, or personal attraction to me which, with the title being what it is, seems required.

Most of them are from people who don't know how to use Win 10 and or are unfamaliar with thier peripherals. I'm not going to review this game as I don't even want to admit that I played it. (No, it's not that bad) I will say this though, remove the "You're out of bounds" warning and place the occupant closer to the user. Allow users to interact with the cards and physically select which one's they wish to use. Also, reduce the transition time from thier idle pose to them speaking. That breaks the immersion a fair bit. And allow users to change the backround. (Non 3D enviroments or just better optimized ones) Even a 360° Photo would've been fine. The current one is pretty resource intensive and prevented me from being able to super sample on my GTX 1060.

 Alright, to get the game working properly: Press Start on your keyboard and toye in "Cortana". Press Enter,  Click the first slider under "Hey Cortana". It will say "Let Cortana respond to "Hey Cortana.". Close that. Next, press Start again and type "Sound". Your audio control panel should now be open. Click on the "Recording" tab, right click on your Oculus Rift and set it as "Default Device". Right click it again and set "Default Communication Device." Now, close that and launch the game. Enjoy.

As intriguing the title or description makes it, don't download it... nothing with falling in love here. There is no conversation or element of randomness in this, not 1%! There's just a list of questions and answers, like a video playlist and you just decide if you want to play video 1 or 2. The outcome? Always the same, you say "I liked it" or "I didn't like it" and it tells you "You liked it? Amazing, now you must be in love"... right? That's how love is working? Right? Noooo... Just don't! Move on to better apps... I have played mating or similar games without VR, that were more fun and had actually some challenge or randomness or anything that would make it interesting. This? Nothing! An environment, a video player and 2 buttons to click on, to select video 1 or 2 to listen to... ZZzzzzzzz.......

review_title: Fell in love & asked her to marry me
one_reviews_text: So in this game, I went out on a date with Grace Van Dien.  The surrounding environment was very serene and romantic.  I started things off on the date with a game of 21 questions with Grace.  She would answer whichever of the two questions I decided from the cards the game provided.  Things were going so well, that I had to tell Grace that I had a great time and would love to continue.  Grace agreed and so I asked more questions.  Each time, Grace would answer in the most honest and sincere manner.  Not only is Grace a very beautiful woman, but she had the most impeccable facial expressions that conveyed our mutual trust and growing spiritual connection.  She would smile, and blush and just had a soft fragility showing from the squint of her eyes.  We were having such a great time together that I was hoping the day would never end.  This was a magical first date.  After all the question cards were gone, I had one final question.  "Grace, will you marry me?"  She did not answer but she did say she had a great time and then the screen went black and back to menu.  Heartbroken, I took off my HMD and silently cried....  Rating 10/10  could have missed the pain, but I'd of have to miss the Dance

review_title: i can talk but that wont help me
one_reviews_text: I can talk but nothing happens it's like nothing picks up my voice and I'm stuck at the beginning. Is the Rift microphone broken? Nah, it's the app that's broken. If there are more requirements than whats listed, please update the info

A nice idea. The surroundings are a little simple, but that may be so you can better focus on the conversation element with the actors, but in I found the graphic style detracts. 

The actors do a great job, but the transition between idle and answering is too noticeable. Its like a complete shift. Seemless would be difficult to achieve, but it could definately be a lot better and help with immersion. When idle the actors could do with more variations. Some just sit absolutely still.

The actors appear very flat so the immersion is lost as you know you're watching a recorded video.  The videos need depth / dimension.

Completely touch free so no interaction. If you could hold the cards and throw away ones you don't want to ask that would be something.

It's a nice idea, great that it's free, needs improvement, but a fantastic start!
I can talk and the game wont start... ever..
mindless, not recommended,
I'm embarrassed to say I was duped into thinking this was a good idea... This was a giant waste of time and human dignity

I had to scream into my mic to trigger dialouge, and I have a booming voice that tends to make mics pop. The actors were talented enough, but it felt scripted and none of them are that into you. In fact, a few had that "rabbit in the headlights" look, like they just realized they are speed dating serial killers. They others seemed to be trying out for the part. Dated them all and my aunt who is 93 hears better than any of them. It's so bad it's actually funny.

First of all, to anyone having trouble getting this to recognize your speech, make sure you have the Rift set as your default recording device.  It will not work otherwise.

With that techincal caveat out of the way, it's surprisingly immersive, even though the actors are 2D videos superimposed on a 3D environment.  At many times I found myself frustrated not because of the experience itself, but because I genuinely wanted to comment on something being said, or go off script.  I have to wonder what an experience like this could be like if a true AI were involved, that could interpret anything being said or asked, and respond with relevant questions.

While this experience is rather short, it's quite unique, and unlike anything I've ever experienced in VR before.  A nice touch is that if the interpreter didn't understand what I said, the characters responded appropriately, asking if I could repeat myself.

I would rate this a 5 if the videos were presented in 3D; that's really the only thing that truly breaks the immersion.  I can even overlook the brief fade transition from one video to another.

This title is complete JUNK.  It does not even understand normal speech.  I am fluent in English and speak as normall as you do, but it cannot even move past the initial speech test screen.

Someone should fire the guys who made this or cut their funding, you are wasting your investment dollars.....seriously.
not even close

review_title: As Two-dimensional as the Actor Opposite
one_reviews_text: I hope  this concept gets updates and grows over time.  As-is it is tedious and unnatural.  Having worked in radio and having done voice work in the U.S. it did an okay job recognizing my verbal queues but in order for that to happen I had to read the cards as if I were reading copy for a commercial.  I did not feel like I was in conversation but at work on an interview with a relatively uninteresting guest.  I have used IVR systems on commercial telephone networks that had better voice recognition capabilities than this.  With such a limited and practically un-interactive response pool it feels like I have to do very complex and uncomforatble things to accomplish something incredibly simple.  When the two-dimensional video sitting across from me jump-cuts to a response it feels entirely like the fresh start of a YouTube video I would never voluntarily watch.  If anything, this works as a perfect demonstration of methods to distract the audience from any hope of immersion.  The little time I could tolerate the experience was spent fighting to connect at any emotional level and the vacant responses only added to the questionable significance of the validity of that "36 Questions" article this junkware was apparently inspired by.  I don't blame any of the actors for that.  I think that given a compelling format and decent writing they could deliver on the promise of connection via experience.  I felt more meanigful emotional responses in the Technolust VR narrative than in this.  My plea: work out the bugs, improve the presentation, involve the audience, vary the content, learn the psychology needed to minimally immerse the viewer, loosen the restrictive format and don't assume the end-user is always going to be the same soulless drone that thinks things are brilliant because they are marketed that way.
Although it was a short session per person, i really enjoyed learning their stories. Logan was my favorite of the bunch. I Recommend this game. I mean why not, its free and it works!

review_title: Why three guys and only 2 girls?
one_reviews_text: Works as advertized. Voice questions understood every time. More girls please! The developers could really build on this. Especially with more flirty/sexy overtones. Make us WANT really WANT these girls!

I'm a swedish guy and I'm pretty fluent in English, but the game refuses to recognise my voice at all. 
I have been streaming for years and have, as long as I can remember, allways been asked if I'm from America, and I allways get shocked results when I say that I'm from Sweden. 
I don't know how perfect your accent have to be to play this game, I guess the only people that can actually play this probably lives on the same street as the developer. 
This looked like an interesting idea, but there's no way for me to try it as I apparently have the accent of a person who have been speaking English for a day.

No really interaction as you can imagine...you just read one of the 2 questions proposed to you, and it activate the answer in video... no interest at all... concept could have been great but the promise is not honored !

The name of this "game" is quite misleading. A more accurate name would be "Dating Simulator" because that's all it is. You sit and ask questions to someone. There's literally no way that love even enters into the equasion. Also, they never ask you any questions. You are the one doing all the question asking. It gets pretty tedious. It's an interesting concept, but way too short and completely one sided.

I thought this experience would give more freedom, but at the end of the day it's just scripted dialogues. Actors are cool but they are just in 2D and the poor animations (visible transitiond from one clip to another) completely break immersion. Cool thing is that it's free and Grace is very cute, albeit deaf AF.

The characters are just 2d videos in a 3d world.  They should have focused on one male and one female and worked to increase the realism.  When you ask a question it blends into the next character video - it blends poorly - it isnt natural.   Voice recognition isnt working great as I have to repeat questions 2-3 times.

review_title: Great concept, still early to work
one_reviews_text:
I absolutely LOVE the concept.
However, there is many little things killing it.
1- Voice Recognition Support
You should definitly give a process to make it work for everyone, I've spent 2 hours to find where my problem came from. For non-native English users, we have to download the English voice recognition pack and activate it by default.
Even if I have a very good and fluent english accent, I have to repeat 3/4 times each questions, taking a neutral and loud voice breaking the immersion. It's a shame :/
2- Spatial game area recognition
I've been litteraly playing from the left of the table, midget sized since the Oculus Position Reset doesn't work with the game. I should have been inside a wall to be well positionned in the table ...
3- It's too obvious that the characters are 2D and between each questions, the jump cut isn't natural at all.
5- What about more cards at the same time to ask questions being more free ? What about the characters asking us questions to make us think also ?
If all of these suggestions are incorporated, it could be one of the mandatory experience on the Rift.
Great potential but not quite there yet ;-)

review_title: The girl is flat as a pancake.
one_reviews_text: Nice concept, poorly executed. While the scenery is in real 3D, the characters are just a video on a flat rectangle that constantly face you. Obduction used the same technique but with stereoscopic video and it was somwhat good. And the worst offender : my feet are 1 feet below the ground? Have you even try your own creation before posting it on the Oculus store?

First, for those expressing trouble with voice pickup, I found that it doesn't use the input specified by Oculus Home but rather the one specified by Windows. You'll have to switch your Windows default mic to be the Rift microphone.

Anyway, it is a relaxing experience that does feel a bit like conversation, with sometimes very charming personalities. But be aware that you will be asking all the questions, and they giving all the answers. Of course, I suppose it couldn't reasonably be done any other way, but the description and even the dialogue gave a different impression, with Grace in particular asking, "We have questions to ask each other, would you like to go first?" So, I was confused for a while about whether the dynamic was going to eventually change.

I can't say there was any falling in love, but it's pleasant. I can imagine therapeutic use especially.

I like what's been tried here. A new and imaginative attempt at deepening your emotional engagement by making you read out getting-to-know-you question cards verbally. Personally, I just felt silly speaking aloud to my computer, and didn't really form any additional emotional attachment at all.

From the basic graphical setting and slightly amateurish UI, I guessed it was mainly the work of one person. I was surprised to count well over 50 names in the credits screen!

review_title: You just cant love flat people.
one_reviews_text: The "people" are flat. Literally. In both proportion and personality. The voice recognition is nothing more than the program understanding one of a dozen pre-scripted questions that no one in their right mind would ask a stranger if they were trying to get to know them. WARNING: DO NOT ask actual people any of these questions. They will possibly call the cops to report a nutjob stalking them. The models are just FMV that plays a clip of them answering the ridiculous questions. They look like flat cardboard that plays video. The program ran fine with no problems, but the graphics, both FMV and rendered, looked pretty bad. The forest surroundings looked like they were rushed, and the immersion was non existent due to the poor visuals. Free is too high a price for this shovel ware.

Mic works everywhere else but i just cant activate at the opening line. did everything so far suggested including speaking louder, changing my accent and setting up windows for the oculus mic as default.

I've tried this app on 3 computers. All computers are gaming PCs with 1080+ and 16GB ram which are meant for VR. The first was stuck loading after the Oculus Studios screen in a black loading area. The second is unable to move beyond the first spoken audio section. The final was able to play the app...unfortunately. What a nightmare. Flat characters, awkward transitions, obvious actors, and the worst 360 environment I've ever seen. By Oculus. The most buggy mess I've played on the Rift. By Oculus. Makes me not trust Oculus even more.

Especially considering the size. The scenery was bland for a 9 gig install. The video of the girls and guys was not up to par either.  No idea why some reviews and video's call this AI at all to be honest. You ask the Person 2 predefined questions and get back two predefined answers. Thats not Artificial intelligence at all. I want to ask them real question of my own. Not your questions!  I expect somethign liek this 2-3 years ago when AI and Oculus was just taking off. Right now though, I expect more.  Uninstalling because this is lame!

Anything would have been better than 2D cardboard cutout people.. Maybe use 8i or make a crappy quality kinect 3D scan. This would have been an interesting experience but I could not look past the billboard people.
"I can speak and the characters can answer"

review_title: Better than the other reviews suggest
one_reviews_text: It's an interesting experience. I had no issues with the audio picking up the right question every time. It's a first direction, but you can see where this could go in the future with ai, making you think of her. Very different to other VR experiences, I'm keen to try it on a few people and see what they think.

As a free offering it was an enjoyable experience. Its the beginning but I would love to see more things like this as the experience seems real for a first attempt. The proram worked well when I set my mic to rift in the sound preferences. True AI with questions both ways and retention of information would be a vast improvement. The actors were good and seemed real. Thanks for trying this and offering it.

Where to begin? There's not much variation in the characters. Four white characters and one African American, all in their early 30s. Secondly this is all scripted. You're asking scripted questions and getting canned responses. Thirdly the speech recognition is horrible. Given that you can only ask two questions at a time it's surpring that it's so difficult for this app to recognize what you're saying. I'm only giving it 2 stars because it was free. If I had to pay for this I'd be upset right now.

review_title: Well it was free I guess
one_reviews_text:
But it wasn't great. Interesting concept but like others have said, there's a couple of volume problems. First is that the audio is WAY too loud. Next is the mic sensitivity must be too low as I had to raise my voice for it to register. I speak pretty clearly without any kind of strong accent (you'd never be able to guess where I'm from) and I found myself having to repeat myself a lot, so I was annoyed most of the time. 
The video transitions were not smooth from idling to answering and back. 
The actors played roles not natural to them. Some of their responses seemed so far out of character for their personality type that it pulled me out of whatever immersion was there. 
The messaging is misleading. I expected AI, however all that's there is a series of recorded videos. 
One last gripe is that the people are almost flat in front of you and the image constantly turns to face you. So like they look 3 inches deep and the turning motion is unnatural. 
In my opionion, this app fails to do what it tries to do almost entirely, so 1 star (but not zero, it was interesting enough for one runthrough).
Oculus, are you serious? This is simply a set of pre-recorded videos. Waste of time.
